opinions.snippet:
Johnson, J.,
concurring in part and dissenting in part: I wholeheartedly join with Justice Beier’s concurrence and dissent and fully embrace her well-reasoned legal analysis. I write separately only to share some of my observations about K.S.A. 60-19a02, viewed through the lens of practicality and common-sense, rather than constitutional jurisprudence. For simplicity, I will use the term “doctor”

caseNameFull: The State of Ohio v. Blackburn
judge: Connor, Cupp, Donnell, Lanzinger, Moyer, Pfeifer, Stratton

opinions.snippet:
Lanzinger, J.,
dissenting.
{¶ 24} I respectfully dissent and would affirm the judgment of the court of appeals. The majority creates an artificial distinction between a waiver of speedy-trial rights and the tolling of time that occurs by operation of R.C. 2945.72. In both situations, the speedy-trial clock stops running, to the benefit of the state. I would hold that the reasoning of State v. Adams

OPINION BY JUSTICE CLEO E. POWELL

Hon. Anthony J. Battaglia, United States District Judge

opinions.snippet: I respectfully dissent from the denial of the petition for the writ of certiorari in this case. caseName: In Re the Adoption of Jon L.
caseNameFull: In Re the ADOPTION OF JON L.

opinions.snippet:
STARCHER, J.,
concurring.
In the instant ease, the majority opinion crafted a “bright-line” rule: in an adoption proceeding, the adoptive parent has exclusive authority to change the adopted child’s name. In the case of a step-parent adoption, where the adoptive step-parent is married to the child’s parent, nobody except the child’s parent has any right to interpose a legal objection to changing the child’
